slides.content:
Fractions represent parts of a whole. When you share a pizza with friends, you're using fractions!

In this lesson, you'll learn:

  • What fractions are and how to read them
  • Types of fractions (proper, improper, mixed)
  • How to add and subtract fractions
  • How to multiply and divide fractions
  • Comparing and simplifying fractions
slides.tip: Think of fractions as pieces of a whole - like slices of a pizza or pieces of a chocolate bar!

slides.title: What is a Fraction?
slides.content:
A fraction shows part of a whole. It has two numbers separated by a line:

Parts of a fraction:

  • Numerator (top number): How many parts you have
  • Denominator (bottom number): How many equal parts the whole is divided into
  • Fraction bar: The line between them (means "divided by")

We write fractions like this: 3/4 or ¬≥‚ÅÑ‚ÇÑ

We read it as: "three-fourths" or "three over four"
slides.example:
Example:

If you cut a pizza into 8 equal slices and eat 3 slices:

You ate 3/8 (three-eighths) of the pizza

There are 5/8 (five-eighths) left

  • Numerator: 3 (slices eaten)
  • Denominator: 8 (total slices)

slides.title: Types of Fractions
slides.content:
There are three main types of fractions:

1. Proper Fractions: Numerator < Denominator

  • Examples: 1/2, 3/4, 5/8
  • These are less than 1 whole

2. Improper Fractions: Numerator ‚â• Denominator

  • Examples: 5/4, 7/3, 9/2
  • These are equal to or greater than 1 whole

3. Mixed Numbers: Whole number + Proper fraction

  • Examples: 1¬Ω, 2¬æ, 3‚Öî
  • Another way to write improper fractions
slides.example:
Converting between types:

Improper to Mixed: 11/4 = 2¬æ

  • Divide: 11 √∑ 4 = 2 remainder 3
  • Whole number: 2, Fraction: 3/4

Mixed to Improper: 3¬Ω = 7/2

  • Multiply: (3 √ó 2) + 1 = 7
  • Keep denominator: 2
slides.tip: Mixed numbers are easier to understand, but improper fractions are easier to calculate with!

slides.title: Equivalent Fractions
slides.content:
Equivalent fractions are different fractions that represent the same amount.

How to find equivalent fractions:

  • Multiply both numerator and denominator by the same number
  • Divide both numerator and denominator by the same number

Example: 1/2 is equivalent to:

  • 2/4 (multiply by 2)
  • 3/6 (multiply by 3)
  • 4/8 (multiply by 4)
  • 5/10 (multiply by 5)
slides.example:
Finding equivalents:

1/3 = ?/12

  • 3 √ó 4 = 12
  • So multiply numerator by 4: 1 √ó 4 = 4
  • Answer: 4/12

6/8 simplified:

  • Both divisible by 2: 6√∑2 = 3, 8√∑2 = 4
  • Answer: 3/4
slides.tip: Always simplify your answer to the smallest equivalent fraction (lowest terms)!

slides.title: Adding & Subtracting Fractions (Same Denominator)
slides.content:
When fractions have the same denominator, addition and subtraction are easy!

Steps:

  1. Keep the denominator the same
  2. Add or subtract the numerators
  3. Simplify if possible

Why it works: You're just counting pieces of the same size!
slides.example:
Addition Example:

2/7 + 3/7 = ?

  • Keep denominator: 7
  • Add numerators: 2 + 3 = 5
  • Answer: 5/7

Subtraction Example:

5/8 - 2/8 = ?

  • Keep denominator: 8
  • Subtract numerators: 5 - 2 = 3
  • Answer: 3/8
slides.tip: Think of it like pizza slices - if the slices are the same size, you can just count them!

slides.title: Adding & Subtracting Fractions (Different Denominators)
slides.content:
When denominators are different, we need to find a common denominator first!

Steps:

  1. Find the Least Common Multiple (LCM) of the denominators
  2. Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with the common denominator
  3. Add or subtract the numerators
  4. Simplify if possible
slides.example:
Example: 1/3 + 1/4

Step 1: LCM of 3 and 4 = 12

Step 2: Convert to common denominator

  • 1/3 = 4/12 (multiply by 4)
  • 1/4 = 3/12 (multiply by 3)

Step 3: Add numerators

  • 4/12 + 3/12 = 7/12

Answer: 7/12
slides.tip: The easiest common denominator is often just multiplying the two denominators together!

slides.title: Multiplying Fractions
slides.content:
Multiplying fractions is actually easier than adding them!

Steps:

  1. Multiply the numerators together
  2. Multiply the denominators together
  3. Simplify the result

Remember: You DON'T need a common denominator for multiplication!
slides.example:
Example: 2/3 √ó 3/5

Step 1: Multiply numerators

  • 2 √ó 3 = 6

Step 2: Multiply denominators

  • 3 √ó 5 = 15

Step 3: Result = 6/15

Step 4: Simplify (divide by 3)

  • 6√∑3 = 2, 15√∑3 = 5

Answer: 2/5
slides.tip: Look for numbers you can simplify BEFORE multiplying - it makes the math easier!
